answers: enriched uranium [accept low-enriched uranium; accept uranium-235]
parts: Name this “enriched” nuclear fuel which contains a certain isotope with atomic mass 235.
Uranium enrichment is usually done with one of these devices for isotopic separation. Enrichment can be carried out using a Zippe (“zip-uh”)-type one of these devices filled with hexafluoride gas.
MOX fuel usually contains plutonium mixed with this form of uranium. This form of uranium consists of the leftover uranium after enrichment and has a lower content of fissile material.
Name this home country of the German-speaking author Herta Müller. A play by a writer from this country opens in an “English interior” where an “English clock strikes 17 English strokes.”
This Romanian playwright of The Bald Soprano also wrote a work in which the citizens of a town begin turning into the title animal in his play Rhinoceros.

This recurring character is the only remaining human at the end of Rhinoceros. This character also pursues a murderer who drowns his victims by offering to show them a “picture of the colonel” in Ionesco’s play The Killer.

answers: Tengriism [or Tengrianism; accept any answer which mentions the god Tengri]
parts: Most Turkic peoples today practice this largest of the major branches of Islam, whose name comes from a word for the broad body of orthodox Islamic customs. It is often contrasted with Shi’a Islam.
Many early Turkic peoples adopted this religion, founded by a namesake prophet in the Sassanid Persian empire, which holds that a “World of Light” existed before the first creation.

This name is commonly given to the traditional pagan religion practiced by many Turkic peoples, as well as Mongols and some neopagan revivalists. Its name comes from the Turkic god of the great blue sky.

answers: gharial [or gavial; accept Gavialis gangeticus; accept fish-eating crocodile; do NOT accept or prompt on “false gharial,” “Malayan gharial,” or “Sunda gharial”]
parts: Name this set of structures that are bypassed by the foramen of Panizza through a shunt. Ischiopubis muscles cause the hips to swing downwards and pull the liver down to make room for them in the “hepatic piston” method.

Adaptations such as the presence of the foramen of Panizza in the heart of these animals allow for prolonged submergence. Members of this order can kill prey using a death roll and it contains caimans and alligators.
This crocodile native to the Indian subcontinent is one of the longest crocodiles and contains a distinctive boss at the end of its snout that may serve as a sound resonator when bubbling underwater.
Name this set of four piano works by Frederic Chopin. The first one, in G minor, begins with a striking Neapolitan sixth arpeggio.
This composer wrote his four Opus 10 piano ballades at the same time he began his long-lasting friendship with Clara Schumann. This composer of the German Requiem also wrote a famous lullaby.
This French composer wrote a Chopin-influenced Opus 19 piano ballade in F-sharp, as well as thirteen piano nocturnes. His best-known piano work is likely his Dolly Suite for piano four-hands.
Name this country where aboriginal children between 1900 to 1970 are referred to as the Stolen Generation.
Australia’s government defines Aborigines as distinct from an indigenous group named for this strait, which separates Papua New Guinea and Queensland’s Cape York Peninsula.

Most of the population of this historical region within Australia’s Northern Territory consists of Aborigines, many of whom live in “oustations” and are part of the Yolngu people. This region, named for a Dutch city, juts into the Gulf of Carpentaria west of Cape York.

answers: Unit 731 [or Nana-san-ichi Butai, or Manchu Detachment 731, or 731 Regiment, or Ishii Unit]
parts: Name this group within the Epidemic Prevention and Purification Department. A guy actually named Colonel Sanders brought it to the attention of Douglas MacArthur, who pardoned its leader in exchange for scientific data.

Unit 731 got most of its data by experimenting on live civilians in this region of Northeast China, which was then controlled by a Japanese puppet government. This region’s namesake people founded the Qing dynasty.
Similarly, the U.S. worked to acquire German scientific data after the war through this initiative, which brought hundreds of ex-Nazi scientists such as Werner von Braun to the U.S.
Name this poet who described a “man in black with a Meinkampf look ”in her poem “Daddy”.

Sylvia Plath was associated with this style of poetry whose writers often addressed topics such as mental illness in a personal manner. Another poet from this movement, Robert Lowell, describes being hospitalized in his poem “Waking in the Blue”.
This other confessional poet narrated his failing relationship with his daughter following his divorce in his Pulitzer-winning collection Heart’s Needle.
Name this cold northern realm ruled by the witch Louhi (“loh-oo-hee”) in the Kalevala.
Pohjola is sometimes regarded as representing the land of these people’s northern neighbors, the Sámi. The Kalevala is a collection of folklore from people of this Northern European ethnicity.

This other character from the Kalevala journeys to Pohjola to woo the daughter of Louhi. In a story depicted in music by Jean Sibelius, he dies while attempting to kill a sacred swan in Tuonela, causing a magical comb to gush blood.

answers: languages [prompt on “speech” or “writing” with “what are these examples of?”]
parts: Name these phenomena explored in Philosophical Investigations. A thought experiment about the “private” type of this phenomena uses the example of a man who writes “S” in his calendar when he feels a sensation.
Philosophical Investigations was written by this philosopher who also wrote Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus.
Philosophical Investigations was edited with the help of this woman. This woman’s work Modern Moral Philosophy which introduced contemporary virtue ethics and coined the term “consequentialism”.
Name this father of Bindusara who overthrew the Nanda dynasty to found his own empire.
This advisor to Chandragupta Maurya wrote the political treatise Arthashastra. His attempts to make Chandragupta immune to poison led to the death of the king’s wife.
This other Mauryan emperor converted to Buddhism after the Kalinga War, and was known for building stupas.
Name this splitting of spectral lines due to relativistic corrections to the Schrödinger equation. This phenomenon also names a constant with an approximate value of 1 over 137, symbolized alpha.
The Darwin term can be applied to the fine structure corrections to the spectrum of this system, which consists of an electron in orbit around a proton.
This other effect is also responsible for the fine structure of hydrogen, which arises due to the intrinsic angular momentum of electrons interacting with the magnetic field generated.

This prequel to Jane Eyre was written by Jean Rhyss and is set on a plantation in Jamaica. The protagonist of this novel, Antoinette Cosway, slowly becomes the “madwoman in the attic” after marrying the Englishman.
This character appears at the end of Wide Sargasso Sea after Mrs. Eff hires her to look after Antoinette. In Jane Eyre, this servant is charged with watching over Bertha Mason.

Maryse Condé was inspired by Emily Brontë to write Windward Heights, a novel in this language. Healthcliff’s love for Catherine is discussed in an essay in this language, The Rebel, written by Albert Camus.

answers: On Democracy in America [accept De La Démocratie en Amérique]
The Old Regime and the Revolution [accept L'Ancien Régime et la Révolution]
parts: Name this work that considers the "common point of departure" a key origin of the title form of government.
This French author wrote Democracy in America. He was originally sent to the US to study its prison system.

This other Tocqueville book contends that the anti-clerical rhetoric of the French Revolution was not due to a dislike for religion, but was rather caused by the desire to tear down all symbols of the monarchy.

answers: cave paintings [accept equivalents like cave drawings or cave art]
parts: Name these works that Abbé Breuil studied in Altamira. Another of these artworks is known as the Polychrome Ceiling for its vibrant pigments.
El Castillo Cave contains a gallery of these objects stenciled on the wall in red ochre. Jackson Pollock imitated cave artists by using these objects to sign the top of his painting Lavender Mist.

This Spanish artist mimicked the style of prehistoric drawings in a series of eleven lithographs that depict a bull in stages of increasing minimalism. The head of a bull also appears in this man’s painting Guernica.
Harry S Truman vacationed in the “Little White House” in this Florida city, which names a 1948 “Agreement” between the branches of the newly-created Department of Defense.
Circus owner John Ringling bought a mansion in near Sarasota for this president where he presumably would have vacationed with his mistress Nan Britton had he not died in office first.
This resort owned by Donald Trump was built for Marjorie Merriweather Post before being sold in 1985. In 2017, Xi Jinping was greeted at a presidential meeting in this place.
Name this author of Emma. Another novel by this author ends with the marriage of Elizabeth Bennet to Mr. Darcy.

In Emma, the title character is confused by a charade written by Mr. Elton that describes “the wealth and pomp of kings” of this noun [emphasize]. Emma believes that this noun represents the love between Mr. Elton and her friend Harriet.
Austen also wrote about a novel titled for this location, where Mr. Yates puts on a production of Lovers’ Vows. Fanny Price eventually marries Thomas Bertram in a novel titled for this location.

answers: Lyman-alpha line [prompt on Lyman series; prompt on alpha line; accept Lyman-alpha blob or Lyman-alpha forest]
quasars [or quasi-stellar radio sources or quasi-stellar objects]
parts: Name this specific spectral line which is used to study extremely distant galaxies by looking at its absorption.

The spectra of these objects feature the Gunn-Peterson trough, a term for the suppression of spectral lines with wavelength less than the Lyman-alpha wavelength. These objects are powerful active galactic nuclei.
This effect commonly causes a broadening of Lyman-alpha emission lines. In this effect, the frequency of a wave changes depending on whether it is moving towards or away from the observer.

Her first husband was Gustav Mahler, whose symphony of this number featured an “Adagietto” movement as a love letter to Alma. Beethoven’s symphony of this number opens with a short-short-short-long motif representing Fate knocking at the door.

After the passing of the daughter of Alma and this second husband of hers, Alban Berg dedicated his violin concerto “to the memory of an angel.” In 1919, this German architect founded the Bauhaus in Weimar.

While Alma was married to Gropius, she had an affair with this Austrian expressionist painter, who infamously made a life-size “Alma doll” and depicted himself and Alma in his painting The Bride of the Wind.
Name this 1819 event in which thousands of peaceful protesters were run down by the 15th Hussars and yeoman cavalry.
The Peterloo Massacre took place in this city, a major center of the Industrial Revolution and longtime home of Friedrich Engels, who wrote about its working class population in 1844.
Manchester was given a nickname reflecting its production of goods from this material. A ‘gin’ for processing this material was invented by Eli Whitney.
